title: Wednesday, 21st December, 2016

PM11:13am

To MPS?

11:12 am
BE11:13am

Okay .............

PM11:13am

Shares in Italy’s oldest and most troubled bank Monte dei Paschi have been suspended this morning after fresh concerns about its precarious liquidity position.

Following a relatively upbeat day for MPS shares on Tuesday, the bank repeated a warning over its deteriorating liquidity situation today, noting that its excess liquidity was expected to run out in four rather than 11 months’ time as previously thought. Shares are now down 16 per cent having been halted twice in an already grim session of trading.

The lender said it would get through around €11bn in liquidity by around March, when it expects its net position to turn negative.

The liquidity gap is then expected to deteriorate to a deficit of €15bn in the fifth month and add up to a €740bn hole in 12 months, said the bank.

PM11:13am

Now look I was on holiday when this finally went into a death spin

11:13 am
PM11:13am

And it's stunningly complicated

PM11:14am

But I know a sov-level debt expert who emailed me a load of stuff

PM11:14am

11:14 am
PM11:14am

So i will share this as RAW analysis

PM11:14am

And un attributed

PM11:15am

This is from a week ago -- but if you are following the situation closely the numbers may be useful

11:15 am
PM11:15am

If successful, the revised Monte dei Paschi private sector solution will
lead to the exact opposite of the result intended by EU policy:

1. Unsophisticated retail investors will be bailed in; and
2. Large distressed debt vulture investors will be bailed out.

PM11:15am

The revised private sector solution seeks to convert EUR 2 billion of
subordinated bonds held by retail investors into shares.

This will leave outstanding:
EUR 148 million of AT1 Preferred Trust Securities
EUR 1,125 million of Tier 2 Subordinated Bonds
EUR 454 million of Non-Tier 2 Subordinated Bonds
EUR 1,727 million total

PM11:15am

These securities are held almost entirely by large institutions.
Many are vulture funds that bought the securities at prices of 10-50%
of nominal amount.

If the private sector solution is successful, the remaining AT1 and
subordinated bonds will be paid in full. The first EUR 250 million on
30 Dec 2016.

Result of private sector operation:
EUR 2 billion of retail bondholders are bailed in
EUR 1.7 billion of large institutions are bailed out

11:19 am
BE11:19am

In terms of UK news .....

BE11:20am

There's this Qinetiq deal for a quite small bit of Meggitt.

BE11:20am

"Targets"

11:20 am
PM11:20am

£57m

BE11:20am

It's a provider of unmanned aerial, naval and land-based target systems and services for test and evaluation and operational training, it says here.

BE11:21am

Amazing how much the listed defence companies only sell countermeasures or stuff for training, test and evaluation ....

11:21 am
BE11:21am

... rather than stuff that kills people.

PM11:22am

It's cos they are defence companies, rather than attack companies, i guess

BE11:22am

Ah, right. Thanks for the clarification.

11:22 am
PM11:22am

But I thought Qinetiq was all about exploiting its existing patents, rather than bulking up

PM11:22am

Guess this is just a helpful add on

BE11:22am

That's the gist, it seems. Here's UBS.

11:23 am
BE11:23am

QinetiQ announced the acquisition of Meggitt's Targets division. We estimate that the
deal would be 4%-5% EPS accretive (in a full year) and will provide an after tax RoCE
of 8.9% by year 3 which is aligned with the cost of capital we use for QinetiQ (9%).
We believe the deal mainly brings in revenue synergies.

BE11:23am

QinetiQ
expects the business to generate £28m of revenues and £5.5m operating profit (19.6%
margin) in calendar year 2016. The purchase price values Targets Systems at 10.5x
EV/EBITA, broadly aligned with QinetiQ current valuation levels

BE11:23am

We believe the main strategic rationale of the deal is to support international growth.
With operations in the UK and Canada, Meggitt Targets generates 90% of revenues
from outside the UK, with a broad range of end clients. Our first estimates are that
Targets will grow revenues at ~5% per annum and could provide some further
opportunities to cross sell some of QinetiQ's products.

11:23 am
BE11:23am

Our 225p price target is based on a DCF valuation using a cash conversion of 88%, 5
year profit growth of 1% and a WACC of 9%, which implies a fair value multiple of
11.6x FY16/17.

BE11:24am

And Canaccord.

BE11:24am

In line with our expectations that the company would put some of its cash to
work, we view the MTS deal as very attractive: it is a solid strategic fit, underpins growth
in the Global Products division, and has been acquired at an attractive price. It is another
example of strong progress and follows other recent positive announcements such as
the £1bn LTPA contract amendment (2 Dec) and £109m NCSISS contract extension (30
Sept).

11:24 am
BE11:24am

Demand for high-fidelity threat representation is growing with new and more diverse
threats coming on stream and MTS already provides target systems to c40 countries and
on-site services to 15. The deal will improve QinetiQ's overall T&E portfolio offering, and
with MTS unconstrained by ITAR restrictions and generating 90% of sales from outside
the UK, it will provide a new route to market to accelerate international growth

BE11:24am

"high-fidelity threat representation" .... !

BE11:25am

MTS will form part of QinetiQ's new International business unit and will be reported
within the Global Products division. The business is expected to generate approximately
£28m revenue, £6.3m EBITDA, and £5.5m EBIT in the year to 31 December 2016. 2015
numbers were £26m revenue and £4.9m EBITDA which suggests c.7% and c.28% y-o-y
growth, respectively. QinetiQ has guided towards 0.8p EPS accretion for FY18; however,
this does not incorporate any potential growth through the year which, given last year's
performance, alongside some of the additional synergy benefits of being within the
QinetiQ Group, could provide additional upside to these numbers.

11:25 am
BE11:25am

MTS is a highly cash generative, high margin (we estimate c.20%), and growing business.
The deal is financed entirely from existing cash resources and returns are expected to
exceed the cost of capital within three years. We therefore view the 9x EBITDA multiple
paid as particularly attractive.

BE11:25am

We pro-rata the £28m of sales for the three months remaining in FY17 and for a full year
of ownership in FY18. With expectations that MTS will deliver a 20% EBIT margin for
the year to 31 Dec we increase our EBIT margin forecasts by 20bps, 75bps, 75bps for
FY17/18/19. EPS therefore increases +1%, +5%, +5% for FY17/18/19.

BE11:25am

In line with the upgrade to forecasts, we increase our target price to 285p from 270p
derived from an average of SOTP, target P/E, dividend discount model and adjusted
Quest®. QinetiQ continues to offer the strongest balance sheet in our UK sector
coverage (£166m net cash FY18E) and therefore further earnings enhancing investment
optionality, the highest cash conversion (100% avg. last seven years), and in our view the
greatest alignment to the MoD's drive for efficiency. Maintain BUY

11:25 am
BE11:26am

Haven't seen a thing from the Meggitt perspective, which I guess reflects that it's not too significant for Meggitt.

Meggitt PLC (MGGT:LSE): Last: 468.10, down 3.9 (-0.83%), High: 474.00, Low: 468.10, Volume: 281.50k
Qinetiq Group PLC (QQ.:LSE): Last: 260.20, up 11.6 (+4.67%), High: 265.90, Low: 249.20, Volume: 1.64m

AO World PLC (AO.:LSE): Last: 182.30, down 1.7 (-0.92%), High: 183.20, Low: 179.40, Volume: 94.36k
BE11:32am

We have Morgan Stanley looking at the valuation and saying "whit?"

PM11:32am

whit?

11:32 am
BE11:32am

Scottish for "what?"

PM11:32am

ah

BE11:33am

Though I don't think Miriam Adisa, the analyst, is Scottish so .... um ,,,,, here's the working!

11:33 am
BE11:33am

AO's expansion outside its core expertise may not bring the desired rewards as its lack of competitive edge and weaker brand become more important as penetration increases. Europe remains the big opportunity but is also costly. Valuation is undemanding so we initiate at Equal-weight.

BE11:33am

AO.com is the UK's leading pure online player for large electrical goods. It has a
16% share of the c£3.5bn UK large domestic appliances market. Its high-quality
customer service and delivery infrastructure helped to grow own website sales
35% over FY13-16, despite limited brand awareness. However, our AlphaWise
survey on UK electrical goods indicates that the pace of online penetration could
slow. Multichannel competitors are improving overall propositions, particularly
on delivery. We forecast an 8% revenue CAGR to FY19 in AO's core category,
implying a c20% share of this market.

BE11:34am

Our AlphaWise survey suggests that AO lacks a true competitive edge to win
significant share in other electrical goods categories. Price is the main motivator
by far for consumers. AO's core competencies in two-man delivery and customer
service are less advantageous outside large white goods. Both ranked lower in
importance than having stores. Competition is fierce in these categories, so AO's
weaker brand awareness is a disadvantage. We see AO reaching a 2% share of
this market by CY20, which itself could require significant marketing spend.

11:33 am
BE11:34am

We assume a FY16-19 16% CAGR in total UK own website sales to £767m, and
25% EBITDA growth to £35m. We expect operational leverage to come through
warehousing and delivery. This implies an EBITDA margin of 5%, at the low end
of company long-term guidance. We value the UK business at 154p, or 0.9x sales.
We value AO at 170p, 8% below the current share price. AO is the second best
performing stock among European eCommerce names and, at 0.9x CY17e
EV/Sales, valuation is undemanding. Revenue growth in Europe could exceed
expectations, but losses could also surprise on the downside

BE11:34am

Europe remains a big opportunity; AO could ultimately deliver an additional
c30p here. Germany and the Netherlands already make up 9% of revenues,
despite being launched in the past 18 months. With online penetration lower and
competition weaker, we assume AO reaches £190m of revenue by CY20, implying
a 4% share of the existing market. Our bull case assumes an additional 33p.
Management expects Europe to break even by FY20, but, with a history of
earnings downgrades, it could take longer. We model £70m of losses over our
forecast period and value Europe at 17p per share in our base case.

PM11:35am

That all reads fair enough

11:35 am
PM11:35am

BE11:35am

Capita PLC (CPI:LSE): Last: 491.90, down 6.7 (-1.34%), High: 498.60, Low: 488.00, Volume: 588.99k
11:44 am
BE11:44am

..... after it followed its first ever profit warning with its second ever profit warning, inside about three months.

BE11:45am

And all the stuff we've been banging on about for a decade -- contract quality, revenue recognition, definitions of organic growth, etc -- came home to roost.

BE11:45am

As of today, Goldman says keep avoiding.

11:45 am
BE11:46am

Capita: No FCF growth; remain Neutral
We take no view on the outcome of Capita’s announced disposal plans. In general, we do not expect the restructuring plan to address the major issues related to bidding process and the increasing cyclicality of the business model. On the back of the recent trading statement, we now expect an average 3% decline pa in FCF over the next two years. Our 12m PT decreases to 595p (from 771p), implying a 2017E FCF yield of 7.1%, which we believe is fair in the business services space given our growth outlook, increased execution risks and cyclicality.

BE11:46am

That's part of a bigger note on the outsourcers ....

BE11:47am

.... that says buy Babcock, because it's only slightly like the rest of the sector.

11:47 am
Babcock International Group PLC (BAB:LSE): Last: 935.00, down 2 (-0.21%), High: 941.00, Low: 934.00, Volume: 201.09k
BE11:47am

The increasingly uncertain operating environment in the UK and macro uncertainty
has resulted in a bifurcation of growth opportunities in the UK BPO sector. Capita is
suffering from consistent returns dilution while Babcock’s returns have started to
pick up. While profit warnings by some of the major UK BPOs created negative
sentiment, we think market underappreciates the growth potential of Babcock. Our
12-month price target of 1420p implies 50% upside potential and we reiterate our CLBuy.

BE11:49am

I continue to argue that the dismantling of the guaranteed-value government tender system was what really upset the outsourcers, but can't find the details of that immediately.

11:49 am
undefined
BE11:50am

(@Blue horseshoe: if you want to gamble on what's going on in Clozel's head, you're braver than me.)

BE11:51am

What else, then? @estrangedcapitalist mentions Bitcoin .....

11:52 am
BE11:52am

Which absolutely isn't my specialist area. I mean, you know who to read for BTC coverage .....

PM11:52am

It is intriguing actually

PM11:52am

What's behind the rise

11:52 am
PM11:52am

PM11:52am

BE11:52am

... No idea! But maybe the former! Want a wild and likely wrong theory?

11:52 am

PM11:53am

PM11:53am

either

11:53 am
PM11:53am

BE11:54am

The rally in Bitcoin correlates imperfectly but not entirely poorly with pharmacies in the US coming under pressure to stop writing so many scrips for oxycodone.

BE11:54am

Oxycodone, you'll know, is quite a big problem.

11:54 am

that being opioid pain medication.

11:55 am

BE11:55am

http://www.wvgazet...-rise-of-overdoses

BE11:56am

Now, if the gateways to buying Oxycodone are being shut down, one would assume the black market would absorb some of that demand.

11:57 am
BE11:57am

And what's the easiest way for someone who's not necessarily fraternising with drug dealers but finds themselves needing opium?

PM11:58am

Well, you're going to say Bitcoin

BE11:58am

Well, I'm thinking the dark web marketplaces might fill that void, driving up Bitcoin usage. The demand may not have any more than an incremental effect, but it's one I'm noting here for the sake of noting it.

11:58 am
BE11:58am

Since it's quiet.

PM11:58am

But I really wonder -- someone totally wired, needing a hit -- are they in fit shape to start trying to work out how buttcoin works and play in the dark web

PM11:59am

Personally, i suspect it's mainly chinese capital flight. I remain to be convinced its the computer hijack thing.

11:59 am
